tutorial.title: Subqueries With Aggregates
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn how to use the result of one query inside of another.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: Let's say we want to find customers with an age over the average age. How you would do this?

lessons.title: Intro 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
First, we could use the AVG function to find the average age. This results in one number and we need to find ages greater than this number.

Make sure to pick AVG followed by ( and then age, ).

lessons.title: Intro 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now we need to select the customers with an age over the value returned from this AVG query.

Make sure to type AVG.

lessons.title: Intro 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
It'd be great if we could use the AVG function in the WHERE clause. Unfortunately, we can't do this because it's not valid SQL.

Make sure to pick >, followed by AVG(age).

lessons.title: Two Queries
lessons.interactiveContent: We now have two queries. We need to use the result table from the first one in the filter of the second one. What if we could combine them?

lessons.title: Subquery
lessons.interactiveContent:
SQL allows us to combine queries. Queries that are part of another query are called subqueries, like the one that calculates the average.

Make sure to pick WHERE, followed by age, and finally >.

lessons.title: Subquery 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Start by putting the AVG query into the WHERE clause of the main query.

Make sure to pick SELECT AVG(age), followed by FROM customers.

lessons.title: Subquery Parenthesis
lessons.interactiveContent:
Next, wrap it with parenthesis.

Make sure to pick (, followed by ).

lessons.title: One Result
lessons.interactiveContent:
Remember that a subquery must return only one value for us to be able to use a comparison operator like > here.

Make sure to type >.

lessons.title: Question: Subquery
lessons.interactiveContent:
What do subqueries do?

Allow you to use the results from one query in another queryAllow you to use a subset of SQL syntax

Allow you to use the results from one query in another query.

lessons.title: Question: Subquery 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What do you need to wrap a subquery in?

parenthesis ()quotes " "

parenthesis ().

lessons.title: Example: MIN
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use MIN to select the employee number of the receipts with the lowest total.

Make sure to pick SELECT followed by MIN and then (, total, ), FROM, receipts.

lessons.title: Example: AVG
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select the employee number of the receipts with a total less than the average.

Make sure to pick ( followed by AVG and then (, total, ), receipts, ).

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: We've seen how to write queries with subqueries that use the same table. Now let's look at queries with subqueries from different tables.

lessons.title: Different table
lessons.interactiveContent:
There may be information from one table that we can use in another table query, like the average user age from the statistics table.

Make sure to pick WHERE followed by description and then =, 'average user age'.

lessons.title: One Row and Column
lessons.interactiveContent:
Notice the subquery still returns a single age result because it has only one match in the statistics table.

Make sure to type age.

lessons.title: Subquery
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can now find customer items with an age greater than the average by using that query as a subquery. Here's a preview.

Make sure to type customer.

lessons.title: Subquery - Select all
lessons.interactiveContent:
For customers with an above-average age, start by selecting all the columns from customer.

Make sure to type SELECT *.

lessons.title: Subquery - Filter
lessons.interactiveContent:
The subquery returns the average age. We can use this age to filter entries in the customers table.

Make sure to pick SELECT, followed by age.

lessons.title: Subquery - Parenthesis
lessons.interactiveContent:
Put the subquery between parenthesis.

Make sure to pick (, followed by ).

lessons.title: Question: Subquery
lessons.interactiveContent:
Are subqueries required to select from the same table as the main query?

NoYes

Make sure to pick No.

lessons.title: Question: Subquery 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is wrong with this subquery?

The subquery is not returning one rowThe subquery is selecting a different table than the main query

The subquery is not returning one row.

lessons.title: Example: MAX
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select the name of all the stores who have greater than minimum sales.

Make sure to pick ( followed by target and then sales_goals, description, =, 'minimum', ).

lessons.title: Example: Less
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select the name of all the stores who have greater than outstanding sales.

Make sure to type WHERE description = 'outstanding'.
